Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:Quantifying Changes in Lignin Chemistry During Photodegradation Versus Biotic Decomposition Using 2D NMR Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Lignin is the second most abundant compound synthesized by plants, comprising approximately 15-40% of terrestrial biomass. Decomposition of lignin, therefore, is an important process influencing carbon storage and sequestration in terrestrial ecosystems. Microbial decomposition of lignin is slow, most likely because only a small group of microorganisms have the capacity to comsume these complex biological materials. Recent studies, however, suggest that lignin can be degraded by exposure to solar radiation (or photodegradation), which is purely a physical process. The role of photodegradation in lignin decomposition, and how this process interacts with microbial decomposition, are not well understood. The primary goal of this project is to examine how photodegradation and microbial decomposition processes combine to determine lignin chemical composition and decomposition. In this project, a novel approach using two dimensional nuclear magnetic (2D NMR) resonance spectroscopy will be used to examine the chemical composition of lignin at a molecular level, providing a clearer picture of the structure of lignin, deepening our understanding of how it is processed in the soil.

The proposed study is important to society because of its relevance to our understanding of the carbon cycle, since the dynamics of lignin decomposition have a strong influence on carbon storage in soils in most ecosystems. Results of this research will contribute to a better understanding of lignin degradation, which is critical to unlocking decomposition processes more broadly. This study will also impact a broad audience by providing training and education opportunities for a graduate student researcher and an undergraduate student directly supported by this funding. It will also provide opportunities for undergraduates or senior high school students to develop related independent projects through ongoing K-12 outreach activities and links to the McNair Scholars Program at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grasslands cover approximately 40% of the Earth’s land surface and about 47% of the land area in the contiguous United States. Grasslands provide a wide range of services to society, including providing forage for livestock production, storing nutrients and water, and mitigating the rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration that has been caused by human activities. These economic and ecological services rely on decomposition of plant litter to recycle nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus to sustain grassland productivity. Understanding the pathways of litter decomposition and their interactions with environmental factors is a key scientific challenge that has many applications in forage production, soil conservation, and fire management.

 

It has been recently discovered that solar radiation can contribute to litter decomposition in arid and semi-arid grasslands through photochemical reactions, or photodegradation. Previous field experiments have shown that exposure to solar radiation, especially ultraviolet (UV) radiation, increases rates of litter decomposition. However, the underlying chemical mechanisms of photodegradation remain unclear. It is also largely unknown how photodegradation interacts with microbial organisms in degrading plant litter.

 

Using advanced spectroscopy techniques, we found that field exposure to UV radiation degraded hemicellulose and lignin. Hemicellulose is the primary constituent of many grass species, and lignin is traditionally thought to be one of the most stable constituents in plant tissue. We also found that exposure to intensive UV radiation in summer altered litter nitrogen availability and, consequently, microbial decomposition of litter. Together, these results highlight the importance of photodegradation in degrading plant litter in grasslands and suggest that UV radiation interacts with microbial activities through influencing nitrogen dynamics in litter.

 

With support from this NSF DDIG award, one Ph.D. student, two undergraduate students, and a laboratory specialist received training in new analytical skills and gained practical knowledge about decomposition processes. Both undergraduate students, including one from an under-represented minority group, are now pursuing careers in science. Project outcomes have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at several national conferences, as well as local venues, including interdepartmental seminars and graduate courses.
